block.p: E*Trade and Wit Capital Team Up for Underwriting Acknowledging how hard it has been to break the stranglehold Wall Street has on the underwriting of new stocks, two online financial-services companies, E*Trade Group and Wit Capital Group, said they would team up to compete against their off-line rivals.

E*Trade said it would form an alliance with Wit Capital after that online investment bank acquires E*Offering, a rival that E*Trade helped to finance a year ago. Wit Capital plans to issue stock worth $328 million to the shareholders of E*Offering. [Page C2.]

AOL Agrees to Settle S.E.C. Case America Online agreed to pay a fine of $3.5 million and to restate its books from 1995 and 1996 after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged that the company had improperly inflated profits by hundreds of millions of dollars. For America Online, which stopped using the disputed accounting method in 1996, the settlement is probably of minimal import now. But it could have an effect on other companies in young and rapidly changing industries because the commission's position will force them to deduct all promotional expenses from earnings immediately. Shares of AOL rose $3.125, to $58.50. [C6.]

Unilever Pressures Bestfoods Stepping up the pressure on a reluctant takeover target, the co-chairman of Unilever said that he thought the $18.4 billion offer made this month for Bestfoods was ''serious money'' and that the company wants Bestfoods' executives to meet with Unilever to discuss it. [C2.]

AstraZeneca to Sell Altered Rice AstraZeneca said that it would sell a genetically altered strain of ''golden rice'' with beta carotene in the developed world and also make the technology freely available to the world's poorest countries. [C8.]

Four Main Airlines Struggle in Brazil The four main airlines in Brazil are struggling, reflecting what executives call a hostile financial and regulatory environment for air transportation in Latin America's largest economy. All the airlines have asked the government to make drastic changes in aviation policies to ensure that the domestic industry will survive stronger international rivals. [C4.]

Priceline President to Become Chief Priceline.com, the name-your-price Internet retailer, announced that its president and chief operating officer would take on the additional role of chief executive. Daniel Schulman, 42, left, will take the chief executive title from Richard Braddock, 58, who will remain chairman. The changes take effect June 15. Mr. Schulman joined Priceline.com in June 1999 after 18 years at AT&T, where he led its consumer markets division. [C10.]

Microsoft Updates E-Mail Software Microsoft said that it had developed a software update for its Outlook e-mail program that would reduce its vulnerability to rogue computer programs like ''I Love You.'' [C10.]

Industrial Production Rises 0.9% Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities grew 0.9 percent in April, the fastest pace in nearly one and a half years, as businesses scrambled to meet demand. [C28.]

Toys 'R' Us Posts 41% Gain in Profit Toys ''R'' Us said that its operating earnings rose for the first time in more than two years under its chief executive's plan to increase sales. First-quarter profit from operations rose 41 percent, beating forecasts. [C12.]
